channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Storm Brings Outages to Puerto Rico and Mudslides to Dominican Republic
item.description: Hurricane Fiona left Puerto Rico with a knocked-out energy grid. More than 1,000 stranded residents in 25 municipalities were rescued, the governor said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Fiona hits the Dominican Republic, setting off damaging mudslides.
item.dc:creator: Hogla Enecia Pérez, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Strong winds hitting the beach in Nagua, Dominican Republic, on Monday morning.

item.title: See the Destruction Left in Hurricane Fiona’s Wake
item.description: Photos and video show the extent of the damage, including in Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Guadeloupe.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Three Reasons for Puerto Rico’s Power Outage
item.description: Hurricane Fiona’s devastation partly reflects several factors that preceded the storm.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Darkness in Guayanilla, Puerto Rico, after Hurricane Fiona made landfall on Sunday. More than a million people were still without power on Monday.

item.title: In Ukraine, Glass Is a Precious Substance as Winter Looms
item.description: Russian bombs. Soaring energy costs. Severed trade links. It’s getting hard to fix all the shattered windows in Ukraine, and winter is coming.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workmen installed new windows on the eighth floor of an apartment complex that was damaged by Russian bombings in the northern city of Chernihiv.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Forces Factories to Go Dark
item.description: Manufacturers are furloughing workers and shutting down lines because they can’t pay the gas and electric charges.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glass stems on a conveyor belt at Arc International in France. The company needs natural gas to make its glassware, but Europe’s energy crisis has caused gas prices to surge.

item.title: Judge Overturns Murder Conviction of Adnan Syed of ‘Serial’
item.description: Mr. Syed, 41, had been serving a life sentence for the 1999 murder of his high school classmate Hae Min Lee. The judge gave prosecutors 30 days to ask for a new trial or drop the case.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Adnan Syed in 2016, leaving Baltimore City Circuit Court.

item.title: Where 6 Investigations Into Donald Trump Stand
item.description: The former president finds himself without the power of the presidency, staring at a host of prosecutors and lawyers who have him and his associates in their sights.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Never before has a former president faced an array of federal, state and congressional investigations as extensive as Donald J. Trump has.

item.title: Trial of Trump Adviser Tom Barrack Could Shed Light on Foreign Agents
item.description: Thomas Barrack, a Los Angeles private equity executive, is accused of working secretly for the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prosecutors say Thomas Barrack pushed the U.A.E.’s foreign policy wish list onto the Trump administration.

item.title: After Texas Sent Him to Washington, One Migrant Launches a New Life
item.description: Lever Alejos, who was delivered to the nation’s capital courtesy of Gov. Greg Abbott, has found plenty of work. ‘I feel fortunate the governor put me on a bus to Washington.’
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lever Alejos, 29, is one of a record number of Venezuelans crossing the southern border into the United States, seeking asylum and hoping to build permanent lives in America.

item.title: Mayor Adams Considers Cruise Ships to House Migrants
item.description: New York City’s shelter system has been overwhelmed with new arrivals, but advocates for the homeless say the idea is insulting.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Andy Newman
item.media:description: Migrants from Central and South America have arrived at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan in increasing numbers this summer.

item.title: N.Y.C. Faces Potential Fiscal Crisis as $10 Billion Budget Deficit Looms
item.description: A persistent pandemic-driven downturn has caused revenue from business and personal-income taxes to fall in New York City, while tourism and job losses have yet to recover.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: For the first time in six years, New York City officials expect that business tax revenue will fall.

item.title: A Rural Doctor Gave Her All. Then Her Heart Broke.
item.description: Physicians suffer one of the highest burnout rates among professionals. Dr. Kimberly Becher, one of two family practitioners in Clay County, West Virginia, learned the hard way.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang and Maddie McGarvey
item.media:description: Dr. Kimberly Becher left a meeting at the Braxton County Health Department in Sutton, W. Va. in July. One of only two family doctors in the county, Dr. Becher was diagnosed with a stress-related heart condition during the pandemic.

item.title: Jennifer Bonjean, the Lawyer Who Defended R. Kelly and Bill Cosby
item.description: Jennifer Bonjean has become known for her aggressive approach as she has defended men accused of sexual misconduct in several of the highest profile cases of the #MeToo era.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Herstik and Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Bonjean outside Brooklyn federal court in June, where R. Kelly was being sentenced after being convicted of racketeering and sex trafficking.

item.title: You Cannot Be Too Cynical About Trump (or His Imitators)
item.description: The former president has company in the nether regions.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers and migrants in Edgartown, Mass.

item.title: Don’t Let Republicans Off the Hook on Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: Democrats are letting the G.O.P. off easily by postponing a vote until after the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: What I Saw as the Country’s First National Climate Adviser
item.description: The private sector now sees climate as an opportunity for job creation and economic revitalization.
item.dc:creator: Gina McCarthy
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy at the Natural Resources Defense Council in 2020.

item.title: Our Predecessors Built a World of Winners and Losers. It’s Time for Something Different.
item.description: As the world transitions to recovery from the pandemic, the inequities are only widening, both between and within countries.
item.dc:creator: Darren Walker
item.media:description: A protest last year about making the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine more accessible to poor countries.

item.title: What Joe Biden Knows That No One Expected Him To
item.description: A liberalism that is as ambitious about solving problems through invention as it is through redistribution would be powerful indeed.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.category: Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro; Photograph by EyeEm/Getty Images

item.title: At Summer’s End, a Moment of Wild Surprise
item.description: As equinox nears, the lovely cycle life is happening just behind the place in my garden where the goldenrod and the asters look so beautiful together.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Math Is the Great Secret
item.description: If human beings invented numbers and counting, then how is it that there are numbers such as primes that have attributes no one gave them?
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson

item.title: The Return of Combat Joe
item.description: President Biden’s combative side comes out periodically. That’s when he’s at his best.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: Democracy Challenged
item.description: Representative government faces its most serious threats in decades.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Kahn

item.title: Can the U.K. Remain United Without the Queen?
item.description: Over her 70-year reign, the monarch helped bind the four nations of the United Kingdom together. Her death heralds a period of greater uncertainty for that union.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Diana Nguyen, Stella Tan, Mooj Zadie, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Waiting to pay respects to Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday. The line stretched for some five miles and officials said at one point that it could take 24 hours to reach the monarch’s coffin.

item.title: What Does Queen Elizabeth’s Death Mean for Canada?
item.description: The accession of King Charles III may inspire more discussion about the relevance of the monarchy in Canada, but materially, experts say it’s business as usual.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III accompanied the procession taking Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin to Westminster Hall.

item.title: After Dobbs: Does ‘Big Tent’ Feminism Exist? Should It?
item.description: Anne-Marie Slaughter and Tressie McMillan Cottom on the future of the feminist movement.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: Inflation Remains Voters’ Top Concern. Can Republicans Keep Their Focus?
item.description: Democrats and Republicans are running parallel campaigns, with one party emphasizing abortion and democracy, the other inflation and the economy — and both talking past each other.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Senators Lindsey Graham, Bill Cassidy, John Barrasso and John Thune at an August news conference opposing Democrats’ energy and drug pricing bill.

item.title: U.S. Hostage Exchanged for Afghan Drug Lord in Prisoner Swap
item.description: The Taliban said it had freed an American engineer, Mark R. Frerichs, in exchange for the release of a prominent Afghan tribal leader convicted of drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Yaqoob Akbary and Christina Goldbaum
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Bashir Noorzai, who was convicted of drug trafficking in the United States in 2008, attends his release ceremony at the Intercontinental Hotel in Kabul on Monday.

item.title: Mexico Has Tequila. Peru, Pisco. In Colombia, a Push for Viche, Now Legal.
item.description: Invented by formerly enslaved people, viche, a cane sugar liquor, was long banned, a sort of Colombian moonshine. Now, it’s a symbol of the country’s often ignored Afro-Colombian culture.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucía Solís, a sixth generation producer of viche, selling the liquor at the Petronio Alvarez festival in Cali, Colombia, last month.

item.title: This Acrobatic Hunting Trick Is Straight Out of the Spider-Verse
item.description: A small Australian spider uses a Cirque du Soleil-worthy tactic to prey on fierce ants.
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)

item.title: How to Ease and Avoid Seasonal Affective Disorder
item.description: As the days get shorter and the nights start earlier, take these steps to help prevent seasonal affective disorder.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Vitamin B6 Health Benefits: Can It Reduce Depression Symptoms?
item.description: Here’s what we know about this essential vitamin’s effects on well-being.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: When to Take a Mental Health Day
item.description: Here’s how to protect your mental health in a culture that values work over well-being.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: I Gave Birth, but My Husband Developed Postpartum Depression
item.description: Many men struggle with mental health after becoming fathers. But stigma and societal norms keep them from getting help.
item.dc:creator: Kim Hooper

item.title: Alan Cumming Uses Dance to Get at the Truth of Robert Burns
item.description: “Burn” is an unlikely hybrid: A movement-focused show performed by a famous actor with no dance training, about a man whose medium was words.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
